{"title":"Page 17","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"1?
Opelousas country would be satisfied, Those
who reason thus have surely never reflected upon
what they urge. Let us look for a moment. The
Attakapas and Opelousas are sugar-growing
regions. Where is this sugar consumed 1 In the
West 1. Will not the depots on the river become
also the market for its sale to the West 1 Surely
they would be. Is it reasonable to suppose the
planters would put themselves to the additional expense of its transport, and other charges, to send
it to New Orleans merely to accommodate our
merchants 1 Would not the Western buyer prefer
buying it direct from those depots rather than in
New Orleans 1 Common sense would tell them
it was best for them to do so; it is so far on the
way home to them, and the sugar would be better
from not undergoing the additional rolling of the
hogsheads from reshipments. The wisdom, then,
of such undertakings, is this—that New Orleans
is called upon, and gravely recommended, to contribute her portion of $600,000 to make roads to
carry away from her more than three millions of
commerce ! Every railroad made to bring sugar
to the bank of the Mississippi is a road made to
carry commerce from Nero Orleans. Not so as
regards cotton; that has to go by sea to the North,
to Europe, &c, where it is consumed, and must
come to New Orleans for its market and shipment,
but sugar goes up the river, where it is consumed,
quite the contrary way.
But to return to this road, and look for a moment
beyond Opelousas, its present proposed terminus,
and what do you see 1 The distance from thence
